items.title: U.S. trade policy is ‘radically different' now, Carney says
items.description: Speaking to reporters in New Brunswick, Carney said the U.S. was trying to 'shut out' Canada’s forestry products, making it important for Canada to source locally.

items.title: Manitoba Government's Connected Approach Supporting Primary Care, Faster Discharges: CIHI Report
Canada Post submits overhaul plan to Ottawa amid strikes
items.description: Canada Post has submitted its plan to the federal government to transform its struggling business model into a financially sustainable postal service.

items.title: Thousands fill Bell Centre demanding Quebec suspend law reforming doctors' pay
items.description: Thousands of doctors, medical students and supporters filled the Bell Centre on Sunday to demand the Quebec government suspend Bill 2. The law links a part of physicians' pay to performance indicators relating to, for example, the number of patients they care for or the number of surgeries performed.

items.title: PayPal expanding its buy-now-pay-later service into Canada
items.description: PayPal Holdings Inc. says it's expanding its buy-now-pay-later service into Canada at some businesses, including Ticketmaster and The Home Depot.

items.title: Canada faces recession risk over next 6 months, most financial leaders say
items.description: Business and financial leaders say trade tensions are the most important factor the Canadian economy faces and a recession is still possible.

items.title: Japanese immigrants fought for Canada during WW I while denied the right to vote
items.description: For the first time the faces of Japanese Canadian veterans who fought in the First and Second World War are on display on the streets of Vancouver after a century largely unrecognized and their stories untold.

items.title: MMA gym owners, coaches ID’d at secretive neo-Nazi event in B.C.
items.description: This summer in Vancouver, dozens of people gathered to attend a conference organized and attended by some of Canada’s most prominent white supremacist organizations. CBC’s visual investigations team looked into the event, obtaining images of people there from the Canadian Anti-Hate Network.

items.title: A Tiny Town’s Successful Newspaper Faces a Succession Crisis
items.description: In the West Kootenays, a beloved local paper needs a new owner. Other small BC papers give reason for optimism.

items.title: World Culinary Awards names Baan Lao best restaurant in Canada for the second straight year
items.description: The Richmond restaurant took home the honours once again.

items.title: The Man Who Tracks Silicon Valley’s ‘Nerd Reich’
items.description: US tech titans are building toxic politics at home and looking to export. Gil Duran has a warning for Canada. A Tyee Q&A.

items.title: Manitoba Government Opens New Permanent Rest Stop on Provincial Trunk Highway 6
B.C. animal sanctuary ‘devastated' after avian flu case reported
items.description: Critteraid, an animal sanctuary in B.C.'s interior, says it is "devastated" and facing a "heartbreaking" experience after a case of avian flu was discovered.

items.title: How former Vancouver Canadians performed for the Blue Jays in the World Series
items.description: Toronto lost in heartbreaking fashion on Saturday night.

items.title: Manitoba Government Opens Downtown Resource Corner at Millennium Library
Manitoba Supports Families with New Parenting Website
Manitoba Protects Indigenous Languages with New Teaching Degree Programs
Declaring man in Quebec daycare crash a high-risk offender is unconstitutional: lawyers
items.description: The Crown is seeking to have a Quebec Superior Court justice declare Pierre Ny St-Amand as a high-risk offender, which would impose stricter rules while he's detained.

items.title: Photos: Matt Maltese caresses the keys at the Vogue Theatre
items.description: A multi-hyphenate British-Canadian singer-songwriter.

items.title: PWHL to visit 6 Canadian cities on Takeover Tour
items.description: As the league continues to eye expansion, the PWHL will play 16 neutral-site games this upcoming season. In addition to returning to Edmonton and Quebec City, the PWHL will make stops in Calgary, Winnipeg, Hamilton and Halifax.

items.title: Stellantis takes Ontario auto supplier to court over claims of extortion
items.description: Stellantis and one of its Canadian auto suppliers are battling in court over the price of brake rotors in a dispute that threatens to shutter some auto assembly plants in Michigan.

items.title: Manitoba Grants Support Newcomers, Low-Income Manitobans Through Endowment Fund
You Nearly Missed: Ada Lea promises to inspire at LanaLou's in Vancouver
items.description: "Because anyone can, you can also do it."

items.title: ABBA tribute ABRA Cadabra brings high-energy holiday love to the Lower Mainland this December!
items.description: "We're there to bring joy, connect people, and engage with our audience."

items.title: B.C. ostrich cull started a ‘new kind of war' after birds gunned down, family says
items.description: The Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) carried out the cull at the farm last week and confirmed that the flock of 300 to 330 ostriches had been shot dead.

items.title: First flu death of the season in Alberta amid warnings about potentially tough months ahead
items.description: Alberta has marked its first influenza death of this year's flu season, after last year's season proved the deadliest in more than a decade.

items.title: Measles Update  #44
2 charged in relation to fatal hit and run involving farm vehicle in Nova Scotia
items.description: RCMP in Nova Scotia have charged a youth and a 41-year-old man in connection to a fatal hit and run earlier this month involving a farm vehicle and an SUV.
